author: By Frank Bruni
title: How Democrats Can Win Anywhere and Everywhere
description: Enterprising Democratic governors have had success where it’s by no means guaranteed. This is how they did it.
content: When Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania got an emergency call about I-95 last June, his first thought turned to semantics. “When you say ‘collapse,’ do you really mean collapse?” he recalled wondering. Highways don’t typically do that, but then tractor-trailers don’t typically flip over and catch fire, which had happened on an elevated section of the road in Philadelphia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Schneier
title: France’s Biggest Literary Sensation Tells His Story — Again
description: “Change,” Édouard Louis’s latest work of autofiction, retraces his trajectory from abject poverty to life as a cultured Parisian.
content: Édouard Louis (né Eddy Bellegueule) burst onto the French literary scene in 2014 at the age of 21 with “The End of Eddy,” an autobiographical novel that announced, with aplomb, his own abnegation. The immolation is even more direct in the original French — “En Finir Avec Eddy Bellegueule,” something like “finishing off Eddy,” as others rendered it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: The Clippers Are Short on Championships, but Long on Logos
description: A rebranding effort is underway, yet again, for an N.B.A. franchise that has always struggled to find an identity.
content: The Los Angeles Clippers have struggled for years to shed their reputation as one of the N.B.A.’s most woebegone franchises. Operating in a perennial shadow cast by the Lakers, the Clippers actually have a decent team this season, with hopes of winning their first championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andre Paultre, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and David C. Adams
title: Inmates Escape After Attacks on Two Prisons in Haiti’s Capital
description: The assault on prisons is the latest in a wave of violent episodes in the past few days staged by gangs who have vowed to oust the prime minister.
content: Gangs attacked two prisons in Haiti, including the country’s largest penitentiary, and allowed prisoners to escape on Saturday night, according to Haitian officials, the latest instance of escalating violence and disorder in the country’s capital, which has been ravaged by gang violence for more than two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne and Oleg Matsnev
title: Kremlin Seeks to Suppress Navalny’s Influence, in Death as in Life
description: The Russian authorities vilified the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny with a viciousness that suggested he was more influential than Moscow would admit. Little has changed since he died.
content: When Aleksei A. Navalny was alive, the Kremlin sought to portray him as an inconsequential figure unworthy of attention, even as the Russian authorities vilified and attacked him with a viciousness that suggested the opposite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barbara Hanson Treen
title: Living Slow Deaths Behind Bars
description: Parole reform has been languishing in the New York State Legislature.
content: Scientists have found that most cells in our bodies regenerate every seven to 10 years, on average. This includes certain cells in the heart and brain. Can we assume, then, that our moral and emotional compasses are also capable of transforming over time?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Is Already Looking Toward the Election
description: In its opening sketch, “S.N.L.” offered a parody of a CNN political show.
content: A new poll conducted by The New York Times and Siena College indicated that voters have a wide range of concerns about President Biden in the months before the 2024 presidential election. But “Saturday Night Live” gave some of Biden’s advocates — or, at least, the cast members impersonating them — the opportunity to dispel these anxieties and argue that he isn’t too old to continue in the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: OPEC to Extend Oil Production Cuts Through June
description: Saudi Arabia’s announcement appears to be aimed at bolstering oil prices as growth in demand remains modest.
content: Saudi Arabia, the de facto leader of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, said Sunday that it would extend cuts in oil production through June, noting that it was acting “in coordination with some” other states. Saudi allies including Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates said Sunday that they would also continue their reductions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro
title: How to Grow Old Like Isabella Rossellini
description: “How do I fulfill the rest of my life? That question came to me very clearly at 45, and I didn’t have an answer.”
content: If you go to Isabella Rossellini’s Instagram page — and I recommend you do — you will see the 71-year-old actress/director/model/farmer wearing a giant woolly hat and vest, beaming with joy in the sunshine at her farm on Long Island. Another photo shows her staring off into the distance, her face proudly unretouched. Scrolling through, I often wonder how Rossellini is so comfortable in her own skin at an age when many women struggle in theirs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Monday Briefing: Fears of Anarchy Grow in Gaza
description: Also, Pakistan’s newly elected prime minister and a bard of China’s rust belt
content: Last week, more than 100 people were killed in northern Gaza, health officials there said, after thousands of Gazans rushed at aid trucks. The crush on Thursday led to a stampede and prompted Israeli soldiers to fire at the crowd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: U.N. Experts Say Gaza Is Close to Famine. What Does That Mean?
description: Several criteria, including acute malnutrition in at least 30 percent of children, go into determining that a famine exists. It is not clear who has the authority to officially declare a famine in Gaza.
content: The aid delivery that ended in bloodshed this week showed the extent of Gazans’ desperation, with dozens killed after many thousands converged on a rare convoy of aid trucks. As the number of aid deliveries into Gaza has rapidly dropped and Palestinians struggle to find food, humanitarians and United Nations officials are warning that famine is imminent in the enclave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Aging Bridge Is a Flashpoint in Competitive Washington State House Race
description: Representative Marie Gluesenkamp Perez is running on fixing one of the busiest bridges in the region. Her far-right opponent calls it an “Antifa superhighway.”
content: The first thing Representative Marie Gluesenkamp Perez told donors gathered at a recent wine-and-cheese campaign fund-raiser was of the role she played in securing $600 million in federal funding to rebuild one of the region’s main arteries, the aging Route I-5 bridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 4, 2024
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah Weiner
title: Why Are Pants So Big (Again)?
description: And what the latest swing from skinny to wide tells us about ourselves.
content: At some point in the past few years, as if we didn’t have enough to worry about, everyone’s pants started to look wrong. For an improbably long time, the “right” pants — meaning those that conveyed some socially agreed-upon, base-line level of stylishness — had been, in a word, small. Snug through the thighs, throttled at the knees, close-cut at the calves, on intimate terms with the ankles. Running a minuscule gamut from skinny to the slightly-more-accommodating slim. There were exceptions, particularly when it came to women’s pants. But on balance, fitted was the way good pants were supposed to fit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Ruth Igielnik
title: Majority of Biden’s 2020 Voters Now Say He’s Too Old to Be Effective
description: A New York Times/Siena College poll revealed how much even his supporters worry about his age, intensifying what has become a grave threat to his re-election bid.
content: Widespread concerns about President Biden’s age pose a deepening threat to his re-election bid, with a majority of voters who supported him in 2020 now saying he is too old to lead the country effectively, according to a new poll by The New York Times and Siena College.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: A New Keith Haring Biography Draws the Most Complete Picture Yet
description: In his thoroughly researched “Radiant,” Brad Gooch considers the short, blazing life of the ’80s artist, activist and man about downtown.
content: Modern art can baffle and intimidate. Keith Haring strove to democratize it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: Jazz Concerts Celebrate Met Opera Composers on an Intimate Scale
description: Terence Blanchard and Anthony Davis, recent pioneers at the Metropolitan Opera, returned to earlier works in a pair of performances over the weekend.
content: In the musical “Jelly’s Last Jam,” which just had an acclaimed revival in the New York City Center Encores! series, Jelly Roll Morton, a pianist and composer who claims he invented jazz, pays for his hubris. But while the show occasionally excoriates him, its fictionalized tale revels in his real-world achievements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Mason
title: An Amnesiac Pieces Together a Life From Strangers’ Stories
description: “Your Absence Is Darkness,” a novel by the Icelandic writer Jon Kalman Stefansson, is a complex history prompted by one man’s quest.
content: Jon Kalman Stefansson’s 2007 novel “Heaven and Hell,” the first of an extraordinary trilogy, begins with a sea voyage worthy of Melville. A crew of cod fishermen is caught in a storm off a remote coast of Iceland. The land vanishes, snow swirls over the water. As the waves bear down on the soaked rowers, they must stop continually to punch off the ice that forms on their clothes. It’s a fitting image of both the sea’s terrifying indifference and a desperate, seemingly futile violence from within.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Ohio Fines CVS $1.5 Million Over Safety and Staffing Issues
description: The penalty is part of a settlement of 27 cases involving safety concerns revealed during inspections of nearly two dozen stores, officials said.
content: CVS Health, the nation’s largest pharmacy chain with more than 9,000 locations, has been fined more than $1.5 million by Ohio regulators over problems connected to understaffing and patient safety, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: Texas Judge Temporarily Blocks Paxton’s Demand for Transgender Minors’ Records
description: An L.G.B.T.Q. organization had sued after the state’s attorney general asked for documents on children receiving gender-affirming care.
content: A judge on Friday temporarily blocked the Texas attorney general from forcing an L.G.B.T.Q. organization to turn over documents on transgender minors and the gender-affirming care they may be receiving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: Easing the Daily Reality of My Strangeness
description: D.E.I. efforts have their flaws, but for Black faculty members and students on campus, they can ease a sense of not belonging.
content: Like many African American professors, I teach at a predominantly white institution (Wheaton College) and live in the largely white small city where it’s located, outside Chicago. I have not experienced serious acts of discrimination, but that doesn’t make life simple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Tiny Drink
description: Samantha Podos Nowak makes her New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Verdict on the New Alexander McQueen
description: A confusing debut, but Rick Owens and Yohji Yamamoto prove that originality is the best revenge.
content: That the death of Iris Apfel, the geriatric influencer whose idiosyncratic sense of personal style made her a fashion star when she was well into her 80s, happened smack in the middle of Paris Fashion Week was both startling and oddly fitting. All the appreciations of her life and outfits have been adding up to pointed reminders of how this whole circus relates to the art of dressing, and the way clothing can be an interface with the world in the most expressive, original way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Who Will Win Control of the House in 2024? California May Hold the Key.
description: While the state is solidly in the Democrats’ column for the presidential election, the winners in key districts could determine who runs Congress.
content: As Democrats look to wrest control of the U.S. House of Representatives in November, their fight will fully begin with Tuesday’s primaries in California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Lack of Plan for Governing Gaza Formed Backdrop to Deadly Convoy Chaos
description: Israel has no clear plan for governing Gaza. That is a particular problem in the north, where the fighting has ebbed, and where a deadly stampede occurred on Thursday around an aid convoy.
content: Israel’s reluctance to fill the current leadership vacuum in northern Gaza formed the backdrop to the chaos that led to the deaths on Thursday of dozens of Palestinians on the Gazan coast, analysts and aid workers have said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Desiree Ibekwe
title: Climate Change and ‘Last-Chance Tourism’
description: Travelers are racing to see parts of the world that may soon vanish.
content: A lot of climate discussion revolves around time. Lines rise across charts predicting the next century. Scientists set deadlines for the coming decades. Each month seems to bring news of a new heat record. The sense that time is running out can be heady.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll
title: The Abandoned Luxury Towers That Graffiti Exposed
description: Skyscrapers in the heart of Los Angeles were a financial failure that many people had ignored — until graffiti artists tagged their windows.
content: It was a billion-dollar aspiration meant to transform a neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Imagining a Brokered Democratic Convention if Biden Drops Out
description: Readers react to political commentary by Jamelle Bouie and Ezra Klein. Also: Human skills in an A.I. world; not all fun and games in Florida.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Irina Aleksander, Adrienne Hurst, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Sophia Lanman and Devin Murphy
title: The Sunday Read: ‘How Tom Sandoval Became the Most Hated Man in America’
description: He turned last year’s season of “Vanderpump Rules” into the best in reality TV’s history — and ruined his life in the process.
content: At the end of a quiet, leafy street in the Valley in Los Angeles, the reality TV star Tom Sandoval has outfitted his home with landscaping lights that rotate in a spectrum of colors, mimicking the dance floor of a nightclub. The property is both his private residence and an occasional TV set for the Bravo reality show “Vanderpump Rules.” After a series of events that came to be known as “Scandoval,” paparazzi had been camped outside, but by the new year it was just one or two guys, and now they have mostly gone, too.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Housing Plan Gets a Yes. Community Says No.
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 3, 2024.
content: “A lot has changed in American life over the past 50 years, but the hostility to affordable housing has remained surprisingly durable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Why Elon Musk Is the Second Most Important Person in MAGA
description: With readership collapsing for right-wing outlets, X is all the movement has left.
content: One of the most remarkable developments of the new century has been the concentration of right-wing power and adulation in two men. Donald Trump is the obvious one, the unquestioned king of the American right. But easier to miss if you’re outside the MAGA world is the central importance of Elon Musk.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Dropped My Left Earbud Onto the Subway Platform at Times Square’
description: One more piece of plastic on the tracks, a morning routine and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: ‘Spaceman’ Has an Identity Crisis. So Do Plenty of Sci-Fi Space Movies.
description: With the release of Adam Sandler’s odd, middling and expensive new Netflix film, a look at space movie misfires of the past and how history repeats itself.
content: Not long into “Spaceman,” Adam Sandler’s new somber sci-fi space movie on Netflix, it becomes quite clear that it’s struggling to channel something greater, something better, something already respected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: In ‘Oppenheimer’ and ‘The Zone of Interest,’ We Hear What We Are
description: Does morality have a sound? Both films use sonics and silence in contrast with images. The complex results raise questions about what makes us human.
content: Humans have spent much of history coming up with novel ways to exterminate one another, but the defining feature of modern violence is its technologization. With a chilling practicality, systems and tools designed to enhance productivity can also separate the killers from the killing, stifling pesky human impulses like empathy and conscience. But a bomb has only one purpose. So does a concentration camp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Israel Opts Out of Cease-Fire Talks as Hamas Delegation Arrives in Cairo
description: Israeli officials did not attend after Hamas was said to have refused a request from Israel to provide a list of the hostages who were still alive.
content: A Hamas delegation arrived in Cairo on Sunday for talks aimed at achieving a cease-fire in the war in Gaza and an exchange of hostages held by militants there for Palestinian prisoners, according to an official in the group, Basem Naim. But a breakthrough in the negotiations did not appear to be imminent, as Israel decided not to attend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Go Big With Bibimbap
description: It’s a showstopping kaleidoscope of bulgogi, shiitakes, bean sprouts, spinach, carrots and cucumbers, all drizzled with a spicy gochujang sauce.
content: Good morning. On Sunday, I like a project in the kitchen more than on any other day. It’s a chance to work at the stove without the need to get something on the table in 45 minutes, a time to stretch my skill set. Mostly, it’s an opportunity to explore recipes rather than simply following them. On Sundays I don’t want to fly by wire. I want to fly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Dominus
title: Kate Winslet Pushes Her Characters, and Herself, to the Edge
description: As a young star, she endured Hollywood’s brutal treatment of women. Now she’s putting her resilience and grit on full display.
content: Kate Winslet was standing in front of a microphone, breathing hard. Sometimes she did it fast; sometimes she slowed it down. Sometimes the breathing sounded anxious; other times, it was clearly the gasping of someone who was winded. Before beginning a new take, Winslet stood stock still, hands opening and closing at her sides; she looked like a gymnast about to bound into a floor routine. Every breath seemed high-stakes, even though she was well into a long day of recording in a dim, windowless studio in London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: He Cursed at a Police Officer. Now He’s Caught in a Free Speech Fight.
description: A Buffalo lawyer yelled at a police officer and received a noise citation. He argues he was punished for what he said, not how loudly he said it.
content: Tony Rupp didn’t intend to become a fighter for the First Amendment. He was really just out for some pasta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Sunken Ship Carried Fertilizer That Threatens Red Sea, U.S. Says
description: The U.S. Central Command said the 21,000 metric tons of ammonium phosphate sulfate fertilizer presented “an environmental risk,” while the vessel posed an “impact risk.”
content: A British-owned cargo ship sank in the Red Sea about two weeks after being damaged in a missile attack by the Iran-backed Houthi militia, and the fertilizer it was carrying now posed an environmental risk, the United States military said late Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Vaccination Rates Dipped for Years. Now, There’s a Measles Outbreak in Britain.
description: After a national incident was declared in January, officials have been scrambling to address problematically low levels of immunization.
content: The 5-year-old looked nervously at her older brothers, scanning their faces for any sign of distress as needles were swiftly stuck into their upper arms, the syringe plungers pushed in and the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine administered. Whether it was for her benefit or not, they barely flinched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Patrick Kingsley
title: U.N. Aid Agency Researchers Allege Abuse of Gazans in Israeli Detention
description: UNRWA, the aid agency for Palestinians, is preparing to publish an investigation based on testimony from more than 100 detainees that accuses Israeli troops of abuse.
content: An unpublished investigation by the main United Nations agency for Palestinian affairs accuses Israel of abusing hundreds of Gazans captured during the war with Hamas, according to a copy of the report reviewed by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: The I.R.S.’s Taxpayer Experience Officer Says Open Your Mail Already
description: Ken Corbin is fixing the phone lines — but those foreboding letters are staying the same.
content: The Internal Revenue Service is on a charm offensive, as long as you don’t earn too much money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
title: As Pakistan Installs a Prime Minister, the Road Ahead Looks Rocky
description: Parliament’s election of Shehbaz Sharif for a second term follows a month of political turmoil. The new government faces economic troubles and questions of legitimacy.
content: Pakistan’s newly elected Parliament approved Shehbaz Sharif as prime minister on Sunday, ushering in his second term in that role and capping weeks of upheaval — as well as setting into motion a government facing economic and political challenges that are likely to leave the country in turmoil for years to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Dune: Part Two’ Draws Large Audiences
description: The science-fiction sequel sold an estimated $81.5 million in tickets in the United States and Canada, the biggest opening for a Hollywood film since “Barbie.”
content: “Dune: Part Two” and its A-list cast jump-started moviegoing in North America after a dismal start to the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Russian Strike’s Toll Rises to 12 as Zelensky Blames Air Defense Delay
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky did not refer to the United States, but his words appeared to reflect frustration over a stalled American aid package.
content: Rescue workers in the southern Ukrainian city of Odesa pulled the bodies of a mother and baby from the rubble of an apartment building on Sunday, as the death toll in a Russian attack two days earlier rose to 12. President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said delays by allies in supplying air defenses had contributed to the deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Nikki Haley Ducks and Weaves on Trump Endorsement, I.V.F. and Jan. 6
description: In a Sunday interview, Ms. Haley suggested she might no longer feel bound to support the eventual Republican nominee and also said that she supported I.V.F. but that states should be able to ban it.
content: Nikki Haley suggested Sunday that she no longer felt bound by a pledge to support the eventual Republican nominee, but did not rule out endorsing former President Donald J. Trump, even as she said she didn’t know whether he would follow the Constitution as president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Freeman Gill
title: What’s Hidden in Woodlawn’s Mausoleums? Extraordinary Stained Glass.
description: Many artworks commissioned by the rich and powerful for their final resting places have rarely been seen by the living for the last century.
content: On a sunny Bronx morning late last year, an all-star team of stained-glass experts prepared to enter a dank 1894 tomb at Woodlawn Cemetery that had been opened just once in the past century.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 3, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 3, 2024.
content: An article last Sunday about the artist James Turrell, using information provided by a representative for the project, mis­stated the city where Turrell is based. It is Flagstaff, Ariz., not Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Meridith Kohut
title: How a ‘Body Farm’ Might Help Tackle Fentanyl Abuse
description: The U.S. government brought Mexican coroners to America to learn how to detect fatal overdoses, hoping to show that fentanyl kills in Mexico, too.
content: The two women lifted a stiff corpse from the ground, revealing a squirming bug in the dirt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: The ‘Dune’ Popcorn Bucket and the Golden Age of Movie Merch
description: The hilariously suggestive misfire is a reminder of the days when too-weird-to-be-true film mementos could be found in every kitchen cupboard.
content: When I first encountered an image of the popcorn bucket that AMC Theaters is selling to promote Denis Villeneuve’s “Dune: Part Two,” I stared at it for a beat trying to process what I was looking at. The item is supposed to represent a giant sandworm, the beasts that slither under the desert planet Arrakis. On top of the normal container sits a lid that depicts the cylindrical body of the creature emerging from the ground. The opening where you are ostensibly supposed to reach in to snatch some kernels is fashioned like the worm’s maw with its many tendril-like teeth, here rendered in plastic. The bucket is intricately designed, but appears, well, especially anatomical — to put it politely — and somewhat difficult to use to actually get treats into your mouth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Berzon and Nick Corasaniti
title: Trump’s Allies Ramp Up Campaign Targeting Voter Rolls
description: Calling themselves investigators, activists are using new data tools and disputed legal theories to urge officials to drop voters from the rolls.
content: A network of right-wing activists and allies of Donald J. Trump is quietly challenging thousands of voter registrations in critical presidential battleground states, an all-but-unnoticed effort that could have an impact in a close or contentious election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: In Texas, a ‘Once-in-a-Generation’ Brawl for Control of the G.O.P.
description: Attorney General Ken Paxton is out for revenge. Gov. Greg Abbott wants private school vouchers. Both want to bring down incumbent Republicans in Tuesday’s primary and shift the state further to the right.
content: Rarely have intraparty battles between Republicans in Texas been as bitter, protracted and consequential as the primary contests culminating in Election Day on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: Judge’s Ruling Sets Back Law Meant to Fight Money Laundering
description: An Alabama judge barred the government from collecting certain company ownership data to help the Treasury Department identify money launderers, and called the effort a case of congressional overreach.
content: In a blow to government efforts to combat money laundering, a federal court has ruled that the Treasury Department cannot require some small businesses to report personal details about their owners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glynnis MacNicol
title: Time to Pluck Around
description: Almost 30 years ago, Carolyn Bessette Kennedy inspired my barely there eyebrows. I didn’t think I would be tweezing them back into existence.
content: In late January, when a friend emailed to alert me that her favorite brow person was doing a residency uptown not far from where I lived. I laughed. “I have no brows,” I responded. “I belong to the great Carolyn Bessette disappearing eyebrow generation!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: German Police Conduct Raid in Hunt for Red Army Fugitives
description: Ten people were arrested and later released. The action in Berlin came after one of three wanted members of the militant group was arrested last week.
content: The German police conducted a raid in Berlin on Sunday in their longtime search for three fugitives connected to the Red Army Faction, originally known as the Baader-Meinhof gang, Germany’s most infamous postwar terrorist group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Makes Baseless Claims About Immigration and Voter Fraud
description: At rallies in North Carolina and Virginia, former President Donald J. Trump asserted without evidence that President Biden was urging migrants to enter the country and vote illegally in November.
content: Fresh off his trip to the southern border earlier this week, former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday baselessly suggested that President Biden had “smuggled” violent anti-American forces across the border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: Why ‘Fetal Personhood’ Is Roiling the Right
description: An Alabama decision on I.V.F. has put an uncompromising principle on a collision course with political reality.
content: In vitro fertilization creates life, in the most literal sense. The procedure offers a chance to make a baby, with eggs that are fertilized and develop into embryos in a lab. I.V.F. has helped countless people have children, including couples struggling with infertility and an increasing number of L.G.B.T.Q. parents. In a sense, it’s the opposite of an abortion, which ends a pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: Republicans Nod to Trump’s Influence in Race to Succeed McConnell
description: Donald Trump is looming over the upcoming leadership battle to replace Mitch McConnell as senators weigh each contender’s independence with their alignment to the former president and the party’s base.
content: With nine months before Senate Republicans select their new leader to succeed Senator Mitch McConnell, some are acknowledging the shadow of one figure outside Congress who looms over the race: former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paige McClanahan
title: It Just Got Easier to Visit a Vanishing Glacier. Is That a Good Thing?
description: “Last-chance tourists” are visiting the melting Mer de Glace in Chamonix, France, in droves. A just-opened lift should make that easier. But some worry tourism is only making the problem worse.
content: Claude Folmer was about 40 years old the first time he visited the Mer de Glace, the largest glacier in the French Alps. He remembers enjoying the panoramic view from the observation platform, then taking a short hike down to the ice, where he toured the ice cave that’s carved into the glacier’s surface.
source.name: The New York Times
